sentences.sentence: The day soon came for Wickham and Lydia to leave.
Mrs. Bennet felt miserable( 痛苦的 ) that they had to leave, and would not be likely to return for at least a year.
“Oh! My dear Lydia,” she cried, “when will we meet again?”
“Oh, lord! I don’t know.
Not for two or three years, perhaps.”
“Write to me very often, my dear.”
“As often as I can.
But you know that married women never have much time for writing.
My sisters can write to me.
They will have nothing else to do.”
Lydia left, but the mood( 氛围 ) in the house barely( 几乎不 ) had a chance to return to normal, when a different sort of news arrived.
The housekeeper( 管家 ) at Netherfield had been told to prepare for the arrival of Mr. Bingley, who was coming in a day or two.
Mrs. Bennet was quite excited.
She looked at Jane, and smiled and shook her head repeatedly.
Mr. Bingley arrived.
Mrs. Bennet, thanks to the help of his servants, was the first to hear about his arrival.
She could hardly wait to give him time to get settled before inviting him to dinner,
and it had not even occurred to her that she might see him before she had sent an invitation.
But on the third morning after his arrival, Mrs. Bennet saw him riding toward the house.
She eagerly called her daughters over to join her in her joy.
Jane remained firmly seated at the table, but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went to the window.
She looked out, and saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down again by her sister.
“There is a gentleman with him, mamma( 妈妈 ),” said Kitty, “who can it be?”
“Some acquaintance( 熟人 ) or other, my dear, I suppose.
I am sure that I do not know.”
“It looks just like that man that used to be with him before.
Mr. what’s-his-name.
That tall, proud man.”
“Good gracious( 天呐 )! Mr. Darcy!—yes, it is him.
Well, any friend of Mr. Bingley’s will always be welcome here, but I must say that I hate to even look at him.”
Both sisters were uncomfortable, but Elizabeth had reasons for being uneasy which even Jane could not suspect( 怀疑 ).
To Jane, Mr. Darcy was only the man whose proposal( 求婚 ) Elizabeth had refused, but Elizabeth knew that the whole family owed( 欠 ) him an enormous( 巨大的 ) debt,
and she felt for him an interest at least as reasonable and just, if not yet quite as tender( 温柔的 ), as what Jane felt for Bingley.
Elizabeth sat staring at( 凝视 ) the table, trying to stay calm.
Jane looked a little paler( 更苍白的 ) than usual, but calmer than Elizabeth had expected.
When the gentlemen entered, Jane’s face reddened, yet still she greeted the visitors in a friendly and proper way.
Elizabeth said as little to either of the gentlemen as she could while still being polite, and then sat down again at the table.
She had dared to glance only one time at Darcy.
He looked serious, as usual.
He seemed, she thought, more like he had looked at Netherfield, than as he had when she had seen him at Pemberley.
But, perhaps it was because he could not act in her mother’s presence as he had before with her uncle and aunt.
It was a painful theory, but not entirely unlikely.
She had also seen Bingley only for an instant.
In that short period, she saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed( 害羞的 ).
He was greeted by Mrs. Bennet with such great politeness that her two daughters felt ashamed when they saw the cold and forced politeness of her greeting to Mr. Darcy.
They did not see the gentlemen again until Tuesday.
Mrs. Bennet, meanwhile, was imagining all of the pleasant possibilities that Mr. Bingley’s half-hour visit might mean for her daughter’s future.
On Tuesday, a large party was held at Longbourn.
When they moved to the dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would sit by her sister, as he had in their former parties.
On entering the room, he seemed to hesitate( 犹豫 ).
Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile.
The decision was thus made, and he sat himself beside her.
Elizabeth, with feelings( 感受 ) of great joy, looked toward Mr. Darcy.
He did not seem to have noticed.
She would have guessed that Bingley had been given his approval( 同意 ) already, but then she saw him also look toward Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-joking panic( 惊慌 ).
Bingley’s behavior to Jane showed that he still admired her, although not as freely or openly as before.
Elizabeth believed that, if it had only been his decision, that he and Jane were certain to soon be happy together.
Though she did not dare to feel certain, she still felt pleased by his behavior.
This was her only source of happiness, and she was otherwise in a rather bad mood( 心情 ), because Mr. Darcy was sitting almost as far from her as was possible.

He was on the opposite( 对面的 ) side of the table, next to her mother, and she knew how unlikely it was that such an arrangement would make either Mr. Darcy or her mother happy, or show them at their best.
She hoped that the evening would give her and Darcy some opportunity to be together,
and that they could have more of a chance to speak to each other than just their simple greeting when he had arrived.
When the gentlemen came into the drawing-room after dinner, she thought he seemed to be coming in her direction.
But, unfortunately the ladies then crowded around the table where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth was pouring out the coffee.
Darcy walked away to another part of the room.
She followed him with her eyes, felt jealous( 嫉妒的 ) of everyone to whom he spoke, and barely( 几乎不 ) had the patience to give anybody their coffee.
Then she felt angry at herself for being so silly!
She was a little relieved, however, when he brought back his coffee cup himself.
She took the opportunity to say: “Is your sister at Pemberley still?”
“Yes, she will remain there until Christmas.”
“And is she alone? Are any of her friends with her?”
“Her servant, Mrs. Annesley, is with her.
The others have gone on to Scarborough for a few weeks.”
She could not think of anything else to say, but still hoped that he would try to continue speaking with her.
He stood by her, however, for several minutes, in silence.
At last, when the young ladies gathered back around Elizabeth again, he walked away.

article_info.previous: Elizabeth的猜测全部得到证实，是Mr. Darcy费时费力找到了Wickham和Lydia，并坚持付了钱，安排了他们的婚礼。得知真相后的Elizabeth既感激又羞愧。
article_info.share_words: She followed him with her eyes, felt jealous of everyone to whom he spoke, and barely had the patience to give anybody their coffee.

question.cn: Mrs. Bennt对于Darcy的评价是怎样的？
question.en: What did Mrs. Bennt think of Mr. Darcy?

options.cn: 他是一个骄傲自大令人讨厌的家伙。

analysis: 文中Mrs. Bennt说道：“That tall, proud man！Any friend of Bingley will always be welcome here, but I must say that I hate to even look at him.”由此可知选择A。

question.cn: 归来后Bingley对于Jane的感情是怎样的？
question.en: What was Bingley's feelings towards Jane now?

options.en: He did not like her any more.

options.cn: 他还是爱慕着她只是不像以前那样明显。
options.en: He still admired her, although not as freely or openly as before.
He fell in love with Elizabeth instead.

analysis: 文中提到：“Bingley's behavior to Jane showed that he still admired her, although not as freely or openly as before.”可知选择B。

question.cn: 在Lonbbourn的聚会上，Elizabeth渴望做什么？
question.en: At the Longbbourn party, what did Elizabeth expect to do?

options.cn: 她希望尽快离开这个聚会。
options.en: She hoped to leave the party as soon as possible.
She wished not to meet Mr. Darcy.

options.cn: 她非常渴望和Mr. Darcy说话。
options.en: She was quite eager to speak to Mr. Darcy.

analysis: 文中提到：‘She could not think of anything else to say, but still hoped that he would try to continue speaking with her.’可知选择C。
